text: Rot²eknā on cōsa tinezī ten ilzān.
trns: Whoever first enters this castle will be rich.
expl: The verb rotekā '(he) is rich,' derives from rotēn 'money' and the suffix -kā- 'full of; described by.' The word for 'money,' in turn, comes from the more archaic rotā '(he) indents it.' The modern language uses the pleonastic sūrotā '(he) indents [to] it' as the latter has become more commonly associated with the minting of currency.
data: rot²ek-n-ā           on      Ø-cōs-a                   tin-ez-ī      ten  ilza-:n

text: Nā aszā sudā ānnallē ātin mocisrouhxemi xin²tōtaca sūlom²ī ko lōn aihra (ne ate yokhuā).

text: Xum²ā āst²oh² kā osēn īt²oh² renī demī.
trns: We want them to do the work better.
expl: I have variously translated 'they' (3rd person plural) with alē and rami, corresponding to masculine and feminine. The more general ītoh has no explicit gender, and should be used for groups where [1] members are of both sexes (e.g. a classroom) and/or [2] the members are too vast or too general to know (e.g. the population of the United States).

text: M²et²ah² itān, inquē sedulleyā.
trns: You are a legend, and therefore I am envious.
expl: Lit. '(it) causes me to be envious'

text: Losaxē sen²yā iratēn.

text: Nā sesonzā, palē set²ah² tō nuzkēkā ya rōtōen lacism²a.
trns: Help, I just laughed out loud at a digital picture.
expl: A few things to note - the equivalent to the English 'just did ...' is given by the expresion palē tō ..., meaning literally '(I) arrived from ...' For 'laugh out loud,' the root nuz- is appeneded onto the verb as an intensifier. Translating 'photograph' is analogous to its form in many other languages: the full word is rōtōraīn which can literally be broken up as 'image from light.' It is clipped to rōtō(en) in most contexts.
data: nā   se-sonz-ā               pal-ē            set²ah² tō   nuz-kēk-ā               ya   rōtō-en         lacism²-a

text: Isnā bakehzā sū Rossiān!
trns: Don't urinate towards Russia.

text: Rihuī-rihuā setah alūn.
trns: I am drinking (water) repeatedly.
expl: The prompt specifies what I assume is iterative. I mused over a few ideas on how to indicate this, and settled on expanding off of a previous construction (become/grow more and more ...) which uses a raised, reduplicated adverbial form of the verb. The '(to become/grow) more and more' construction can be easily re-analyzed as derivative of an iterative mood since the construction uses the auxiliary -latā 'it becomes (it),' for example: renī-renlatē 'it became better and better.'

text: Tanā ne ten lōn Ali esden.
trns: Ali is in the state of building a house.
expl: The 5MOYD prompt includes an addendum house building currently affects his life, but this is not grammatically conveyed by the language (my assumption is that the paper from which the prompt was taken surveyed a language where this is grammatically salient).
data: Ø-tan-ā                 ne   ten  lo-:n            Ali          esd-en

text: T²ā nēlā essē set²ah² tapā ya m²et²ah² rizquet²en in xeih sorīn, ko cēz t²ā carā essē m²et²ah² nōi.
trns: I really do think you need a mentor and lots of love, because you do seem very angry.
expl: This exemplifies the use of tā i.e. the copula as a clausal intensifier. In English, the intensivity is given by 'do,' as in 'I do think ...' rather than 'I think,' which is fairly neutral. The literal translation is 'it is that I think ...' for tā nēlā (setah). Note also that 'very' and 'really' (in the sense of an intensifier) are lexified equally - this reflects the more overarching nature that verbs and adjectives are not grammatically distinguished.
data: t²-ā            Ø-nēl-ā                  essē set²ah² tap-ā                   ya   m²et²ah² rizqu-et²-en         in  xeih sor-i-:n              ko     cēz-Ø            t²-ā            car-ā               essē m²et²ah² nōi

$cop-$npst.$ind $3sg.$t-think-$npst.$ind very $1sg    be_necessary-$npst.$ind $dat $2sg     teach-$agt-$absl.$sg and much love-$abstr-$absl.$sg $instr reason-$posd.$sg $cop-$npst.$ind be_angry-$npst.$ind very $2sg     seem

text: Petlo m²enari in nader m²enari; sopenā tīē.
trns: Thy rod and thy staff; they comfort me.
expl:
Translating this one involved deciding between a formal and personal second person for 'thy.' In normal speech 'your' is an affix upon the noun (i.e. mepetlo in menader) but in order to respect the gravitas of the original, I chose to use the formal menari 'you' << m(e) 'your' + narīn 'clarity' << narā 'it is clear.'
It should be noted that in English of the time this was originally written, 'thou' is more personal than 'you,' and in many languages the personal T is used in reference to God. My native language (English) does not make the T-V distinction and my understanding therefore of the distinction is academically derived and conversationally infelicitous.
data: petlo-Ø         m²e-nar-i-Ø                       in  nader-Ø         m²e-nar-i-Ø                       s-open-ā                   tī-ē

text: Kuy bosnā ne ruh²maxtūn setaw ko seren ne pos epocyen?
phnt: kʊj ˈbɔsnaː ne rʊʔˈmɑʃtun̥ ˈsetɑʍ ko ˈserən̥ ne pɔs eˈpɔt͜ʃjən̥

text: Mac, kuy eh²t²en on piquena set²ah², eh²t²en on apulna?

text: Aycā tanā Marīa nullen.
trns: Maria would have made the dough.

text: Mikcē luscam²ī nin²ta ne on ne-t²e osuhocēs in lāsē eresū.
phnt: ˈmɪkt͜ʃeː ˈlʊs̠t͜ʃamiː ˈnɪn̥ta ne ɔn̥ ˈnete osʊʔˈot͜ʃes ɪn̥ ˈlaːseː ˈeresuː
trns: Surprisingly, the merchants had left their goods where they were and had run away.
expl: The word eresū is used here to translate the sense of '... away' as expressed in the English - it is a nominally-incorporated prepositional phrase from sū 'to(wards)' and ere- 'area beyond a great distance' << erā 'it is far.'

text: Polhā sū siphuen set²ah² oēlāzhue.
trns: I hang my dress on a tree.
expl: The word ēlāzhuēn, translated here as 'dress,' is derived from ēl- 'woman, female' and āzhuēn 'clothing' << atāzhuōs 'to wear.'
